awd_titl_txt: Conference: 2023 Combinatorial Algebra meets Algebraic Combinatorics (CAAC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Combinatorial Algebra meets Algebraic Combinatorics (CAAC) conference will take place at the University of Waterloo from 20 to 22 of January, 2023. The CAAC is an annual three-day interdisciplinary conference for mathematicians that brings together algebraists interested in discrete mathematics and combinatoricists interested in algebra. The conference focuses on the interplay between algebra and combinatorics and their applications to other areas of mathematics and science. The 20th iteration of CAAC will bring together the mathematical research communities of Canada and the United States, as well as some mathematicians from other continents. CAAC strives to be an inclusive conference that promotes collaboration, development of young talent, and progress in this field.

CAAC 2023 will feature presentations on a wide array of topics in combinatorial algebra, algebraic combinatorics, and their applications. These topics include Newton-Okounkov bodies, chromatic symmetric functions, enumeration, cluster algebras, monomial ideals, dynamical algebraic combinatorics, plethysm, toric varieties, and geometric vertex decomposition. There will also be a poster session for early-career participants to share their work. More details are available on the conference website, https://sites.google.com/view/caac2023/home.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Combinatorial Algebra meets Algebraic Combinatorics (CAAC) is a three-day conference that has been held annually since 2004. This grant partially funded the 20th iteration of the conference, held this year at the University of Waterloo in Waterloo, Ontario. The conference's scope was international, bringing together 108 participants from across North America and Europe. This grant funded the participation of 16 graduate students and postdoctoral researchers from the US.

The conference featured four invited speakers and eleven contributed talks presenting new research in algebraic combinatorics, as well as a poster session with 21 posters from younger participants. 

Intellectual Merit:

The meeting brought together researchers in algebraic combinatorics, combinatorial algebra, and related fields. Combinatorial algebra and algebraic combinatorics are two highly active areas of research. Their importance is felt throughout theoretical and applied mathematics, including algebraic geometry, representation theory, commutative algebra, and mathematical physics; they have found numerous practical applications in diverse fields such as algebraic statistics and computer vision.

CAAC brought together experts in these areas in conversation with experts from neighboring fields and many younger researchers. 

Broader Impacts:

Following the tradition of past workshops, CAAC 2023 built and strengthened collaborations, allow for dissemination of research and contributed to the training of students and postdoctoral fellows. 

Of our 36 presenters, 10 (27%) were women, and 26% of the conference participants who reported their gender self-identified as a gender other than male.  Students made up 59% of all participants, and 17% were postdoctoral researchers.  Of those who responded about ethnicity/race, 8% identified as Hispanic or Latino, 34% identified as Asian, 6% identified as Black or African.

 


Last Modified: 03/19/2024
Modified by: Oliver A Pechenik
